results.title: Land mines: a love story
results.brief_description: Land mines remain a danger in 82 countries around the world, and between 15,000 and 20,000 people become fresh victims of land mines every year. Afghanistan (one of the countries worst affected) is estimated to still have ten million unexploded landmines in the ground. Veteran Australian documentary filmmaker Dennis O’Rourke travelled to Afghanistan in 2001 to make this film about how land mines have affected the lives of ordinary Afghani people. In the chaos of war-ravaged Kabul, O’Rourke met Habiba, a Tajik woman who lost one of her legs to a land mine in 1992 at age 11. Habiba is married to Shah, a former Mujaheddin fighter, also disabled as a result of his war injuries. The result is a film that, while showing the destruction and suffering caused by war, also celebrates life, love and hope for the future. (Awards: Winner of the 2005 AFI Award for Best Documentary).

results.title: Land from the sky
results.brief_description: Records the use of aircraft as an aid to farming in the hill country in New Zealand. From the early days when pilots made hazardous trips in old air force planes - landing and taking off from any strip of paddock, aerial topdressing has today developed into a well organised industry restoring dangerously eroded hill country. Planes are now used extensively for other farm work such as spraying and rabbit poisoning.

results.title: Land divers of Melanesia
results.creator_credit: Phoenix Films, Robert Gardner and Karl Muller
results.brief_description: Documents the salient features of the intact culture of Melanesia, including agriculture, play and ritual of Bunlap on Pentecost Island in the New Hebrides. Shows the relationship between yam agriculture and ceremonies such as land diving.

results.title: Land behind the dikes: the Netherlands
results.creator_credit: John Ferno and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Makes the point that the Netherlands, with about one-half of the land area below sea level, is largely man-made. Illustrates draining, reclamation, farming, the use of canals for transport, and the richness of the polders.

results.title: Land and live in the jungle
results.creator_credit: United States. Army Air Forces. First Motion Picture Unit
results.brief_description: A training film for WWII servicemen showing basic survival techniques for the jungle. Four crash survivors demonstrate how to survive in the jungle by trapping and fishing, cooking and sheltering from the wet. To reinforce the message, a lone airman shows how to do the wrong things. Van Heflin appears as one of the airmen.

results.title: Land and live in the desert
results.brief_description: A training film for WWII servicemen showing basic survival techniques for the desert. When a B24 bomber crashes, the plane’s occupants must organise themselves to conserve rations and energy in order to survive. The lack of water, the extreme weather conditions and the strain of coping during a disaster present enormous challenges to the servicemen. By supporting each other and following some basic rules, the groups chance of survival is increased.

results.title: Land and Freedom = Tierra y Libertad
results.creator_credit: Rebecca O'Brien, Parallax Films, Messidor Films, Road Movies Dritte Produktionen and Ken Loach
results.brief_description: Land and freedom traces the life of unemployed Liverpool lad David (Ian Hart) who, sick of English pessimism, leaves his home to fight in the Spanish Civil War. The story opens in 1994 as Dave is having a fatal heart attack in his Liverpool council flat. Later, his granddaughter is going through his possessions when she discovers a suitcase filled with clippings and mementos from the Spanish conflict. Included are letters from the front, and strangely, a faded red handkerchief filled with soil. The story jumps back to 1936, when young Dave, a communist, decides he will fight the fascists in Spain. When he joins the Republican workers fighting fascist soldiers in the Barcelona foothills, he finds not only a new purpose in life, but also first love, and eventually political disillusionment. Mainly in English, with sections in Spanish, German, French with sub-titles. Multi-award wining film (Cannes, Euopean Film of the Year) directed by Ken Loach.

results.title: Land
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
A series of views on America’s economic history. This film presents an intriguing and entertaining account of how the earth helped shape the destiny of the United States - how the rich, fertile earth goaded people into prosperity. Features William Shatner.

results.title: Lancashire's time for adventure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
For more than 200 years cotton, grown on the other side of the world, has been coming to Britain to be spun and woven. A moist climate, money for the development of mills, and inventors whose machines taught mass-production to the world - Lancashire had all these. But today one-third of Lancashire’s spindles and looms are idle. The memory of past booms and slumps has resulted in a grave shortage of operators. Schemes to improve working conditions and wages have been put into operation.

results.title: Lancashire
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Regional Geography”.
Traces the rise of industrial Lancashire, and notes the importance of the coastal ports in the growth of new industries. Also deals with Lancashire’s agriculture, recreation and housing.
